title: The SAG Awards were one long blast of defiance against Donald Trump. Here are the biggest moments.
text:
By Isha Aran The last seven days have been some of the most tumultuous times our nation has seen.   various executive orders to build the wall along the Mexican border, suspend refugee immigration, and essentially ban many Muslims from entering the country have sent the US into a tailspin. And members of the Screen Actors Guild had something to say about it at the SAG Awards on Sunday night. In light of Meryl Streep‚Äôs fiery tirade at the Golden Globes, the actors had their work cut out for them, and they rose to the challenge. At nearly every opportunity, celebrities either called for support for immigrants or criticized President Donald Trump for his racist and Islamophobic orders. We rounded up every single moment the SAG Awards got political. Before the show even began, Big Bang Theory star Simon Helberg brandished a sign on the red carpet supporting refugees: Simon Helberg arrives at SAG Awards with "refugees welcome" sign https://t.co/ffWx1gyvm9 pic.twitter.com/39F0sHJyU6 Right off the bat, Scandal ‚Äôs Kerry Washington, who wore a safety pin on the red carpet, opened the show saying: Kerry Washington: "No matter what, actors are activists." #SAGAwards pic.twitter.com/l9IlFg8sme 
‚Äî BuzzFeed (@BuzzFeed) January 30, 2017 Ashton Kutcher took to the stage, more directly addressing the Muslim and refugee ban: 
‚ÄúGood evening, fellow SAG-AFTRA members, and everyone at home, and everyone in airports that belong in my America. You are part of the fabric of who we are and we love you and we welcome you.‚Äù Julia Louis Dreyfus poked fun at Donald Trump, joking about the SAG awards being hacked by Russians and of course about the size of the crowd at the ceremony, before going onto a more serious note, discussing her own Jewish heritage : 
‚ÄúI want you all to know that I am the daughter of an immigrant,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúMy father fled religious persecution in Nazi-occupied France and I‚Äôm an American patriot and I love this country. Because I love this country, I am horrified by its blemishes and this immigrant ban is a blemish and it is un-American.‚Äù Upon receiving the award for Outstanding Performance by a Male Actor in a Comedy Series, William H. Macy sent a quick jab Trump‚Äôs way, thanking the president for ‚Äúmaking Frank Gallagher seem normal.‚Äù (Macy plays Frank on Shameless.) 
Viola Davis gave yet another amazing impassioned speech reminding us just how crucial it is for the stories of people of color to be told. 
‚Äî SAG Awards¬Æ (@SAGawards) January 30, 2017 On behalf of the cast of Orange is the New Black (who won for Outstanding Performance by an Ensemble in a Comedy Series), Taylor Schilling spoke about the diversity of the cast and the need to keep telling diverse stories. 
‚Äî People Magazine (@people) January 30, 2017 Kathryn Hahn and Viggo Mortensen did a timely callback to a line from Captain Fantastic with a ‚ÄúPower to the people! Stick it to the man!‚Äù That kind of counts, right? Upon winning his first SAG award, Mahershala Ali, who is Muslim, discussed that his role in Moonlight allowed him to ‚Äúsee what happens when you persecute people.‚Äù He went onto discuss explaining his conversion to Islam to his Christian mother. #Moonlight star Mahershala Ali gives a tearful acceptance speech #SAGawards pic.twitter.com/L45DPQUbeD 
‚Äî Variety (@Variety) January 30, 2017 Bryan Cranston offered some timely pee-themed advice to Donald Trump from Lyndon B. Johnson after accepting the award for Outstanding Performance by a Male Actor in a Miniseries or Television Movie: ‚ÄúJust don‚Äôt puss in the soup that all of us gotta eat.‚Äù Alia Shawkat greeted the crowd with an ‚ÄúAs-Salaam-Alaikum‚Äù before presenting the award for Outstanding Performance by a Female Actor in a Drama Series. David Harbour delivered the acceptance speech on behalf of the cast of Stranger Things (who won Outstanding Performance by an Ensemble in a Drama Series) AND PRETTY MUCH PROMISED TO PUNCH NAZIS IN THE FACE. Okay, he didn‚Äôt say the word ‚ÄúNazi,‚Äù but he definitely meant it. This acceptance speech was great: David Harbour uses 'Stranger Things' win to diss Trump: "We will shelter freaks and outcasts" https://t.co/GbdAsb8jYb #SAGawards pic.twitter.com/DnmzYvP5jm 
‚Äî Hollywood Reporter (@THR) January 30, 2017 And finally, ending the night on a perfectly hopeful note, the cast of Hidden Figures took home the big prize of the night, Outstanding Performance by a Cast in a Motion Picture, and Taraji P. Henson took the opportunity to remind everyone of what happens ‚Äúwhen we put our differences aside‚Äù and ‚Äúcome together.‚Äù When Taraji gives the most inspirational speech of the night üò≠ #SAGAwards #HiddenFigures pic.twitter.com/U1FRL1aafW
